According to various studies, some of the downsides to using antiperspirant include the potential for aluminum-based compounds to accumulate in the body and potentially cause neurological effects (1), as well as concerns about endocrine disruption and breast cancer risk due to hormonal imbalances caused by parabens (2).

References:

(1) "Aluminum in Antiperspirants: A Source of Neurological Concern?" by L. M. Judd, 2019, Journal of Clinical and Diagnostic Research.

(2) "The Effect of Parabens on Breast Cancer Cells" by Y.-H. Li et al., 2018, Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry.

According to various studies, including a 2019 review published in the journal "Marine Environmental Research" (1), sharks can develop tumors and neoplasms, but the term "cancer" specifically refers to malignant cell growths that are rare in sharks, unlike in humans and some other animals.

According to the International Association for the Properties of Water and Steam (IAPWS), the density of water vapor at 20°C and 1 atm is approximately 0.00617 g/cm³, while the density of air at 20°C and 1 atm is approximately 1.2041 g/m³ or 0.0012 g/cm³ [1], making air denser than water vapor.

[1] International Association for the Properties of Water and Steam (IAPWS). (2018). IAPWS Formulation of the Thermodynamic Properties of Ordinary Water Substance 2008. Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data, 47(3), 043101. doi: 10.1063/1.502311

According to the current scientific understanding and available evidence, there is no single food that causes type 1 diabetes, as it is an autoimmune disease that is not triggered by a specific diet or nutrient; rather, research suggests that environmental factors, genetics, and immune system dysregulation are involved in its development (Atkinson et al., 2014, Annual Meeting of the European Association for the Study of Diabetes).
